q1.contents: Which of the following three concepts appeared first? <please select the best answer> A. Artificial Intelligence B. Machine Learning C. Deep Learning

q2.contents: Which of the following two concepts means 'learning by generating rules from known facts'? <please select the best answer> A. Deduction B. Induction

q3.contents: Which of the three ways of learning requires all input data to be paired with correct answers? <please select the best answer> A. Supervised learning B. Unsupervised learning C. Reinforcement learning

q4.contents: Which of the three ways of learning is sometimes the only way we can use? <please select the best answer> A. Supervised learning B. Unsupervised learning C. Reinforcement learning

q5.contents: What are the three components of AI? <please input your answer>

q6.contents: The probability that the number of dice rolls is 1 is? <please input your answer>

q7.contents: What are the cells in the brain that are used for thinking called? <please input your answer>

q8.contents: What are the connections between the cells in the brains called? <please input your answer>

q9.contents: The sum of three angles of any triangle is 180 degrees. A right triangle is a triangle. What can you conclude from these? <please input your answer>
q9.correct_answer: The sum of the three angles of a right triangle is 180 degrees

q10.contents: We have known 10% of patients have liver disease, and 5% of the patients are alcoholics. And we know that among those patients diagnosed with liver disease, 7% are alcoholics. What is the patient's probability of having liver disease if they are an alcoholic? <please input your answer>

q1.contents: The reticular theory was advocated by physician Camillo Golgi, who invented a groundbreaking method for observing the nervous system. <please select the best answer> True or False

q2.contents: For an AND logic gate, if the inputs are '0' and '1', then the output is 1. <please select the best answer> True or False

q3.contents: For an OR logic gate, if the inputs are '0' and '1', then the output is 1. <please select the best answer> True or False

q4.contents: Frank Rosenblatt came up with the first learning theory. <please select the best answer> True or False

q5.contents: The first neural networks winter is because of that training ANNs takes a lot of computation and computing power was limited in that era. <please select the best answer> True or False

q6.contents: For the current state of ANNs, it is easy to interpret what ANNs are doing. <please select the best answer> True or False

q7.contents: ANNs of the current state don't have a good generalization. <please select the best answer> True or False

q8.contents: McCulloch and Pitts found what to be like the basic building block that can be used to build any complex logical circuits? <please input your answer>

q10.contents: What is the algorithm that contributed to the end of the first neural network winter? <please input your answer>

q1.contents: Which of the following learning methods involves learning from a teacher? <please select the answer> A. Unsupervised learning B. Supervised learning C. Reinforcement learning

q2.contents: Which of the following options are required to determine the change of one connection in the delta rule? <please select the answer> A. learning constant B. desired change C. input D. connection weight

q3.contents: If the desired change is positive, and the input is -1, will the weight decrease or increase? <please select the best answer> A. decrease B. increase

q4.contents: After many iterations of learning, what value does the output of the '+' artificial neuron in response to 'x' become closer to? <please select the best answer> A. 1.0 B. 0.0 C. 1.5 D. -1.0

q5.contents: If the input of a single-layer ANN model is 1,0,1; and the weight of inputs is 0.1, 0.2, 0.3; what is the output of the single-layer ANN model? <please input your answer>

q6.contents: If the target output is 0.5 and the computed output is 0.3, what would the desired change be? <please input your answer>

q7.contents: Let the learning constant be 0.2, the desired change to be 0.3, and the input to be 1, then the change of weight will be? <please select the best answer> A. 0.02 B. 0.04 C. 0.05 D. 0.06

q8.contents: If the inner state is -1, what will the output be after the ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit)? <please select the best answer> A. -1 B. 0 C. 1

q9.contents: If there is more than one layer of artificial neurons--- that is, if neurons are between the input and the output neurons--- the delta rule can't be used. Why not? Each artificial neuron has computable inputs and an output. What is missing? <please input your answer>
q9.correct_answer: Desired outputs are not given for these 'in between' neurons

q10.contents: If supervised learning works, the weight change will become smaller and smaller. Why? <please input your answer>
q10.correct_answer: As the output becomes closer to the desired output, the desired change will become smaller.

q11.contents: In a supervised ANN, the input is 0.5, the weight is 1, and we use ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) as the hat of a neuron. The desired output is 1 and we set the learning rate as 0.01. Please calculate the weight change of the process. <please input your answer>

q12.contents: What was backpropagation developed to do? <please input your answer>
q12.correct_answer: Train incoming connection weights to middle/non-input layers

q1.contents: What do humans use to classify objects, for instance, pictures of fruits? <please input your answer>

q2.contents: The picture below shows a decision tree, please list three kinds of elements of a decision tree? And please give examples of each node type in this decision tree? Picture: decision tree of weather. <please input your answer>
q2.correct_answer: Internal node, branch, leaf node (Internal node: Outlook, Humidity, Wind Branch: Sunny, Overcast... Leaf node: Yes, No)

q3.contents: In this form below, which features can we select to decide whether people enjoy tennis? <please select the best answer> A. Outlook B. Temperature C. Humidity D. Wind; Form: table of features and tennis enjoyment

q4.contents: In the I-Nearest-Neighbor method, how should we classify a new example? <please input your answer>
q4.correct_answer: Label x with the label of the closest example to x

q5.contents: In this image about the process of KNN algorithm, which cluster should Xj be classified to? <please select the best answer> A. Red B. Green C. Blue; Image: KNN algorithm graph

q6.contents: Please describe how the effect of the KNN algorithm changes as k increases from 1. What kind of problems will occur when K is too small and when K is too large? <please input your answer>
q6.correct_answer: K is too small: overfit K is too big: underfit

q1.contents: What is the data given during supervised learning but not in unsupervised learning? <please select the best answer> A. Input B. Connection weight C. Desirable output

q2.contents: If the unsupervised ANNs that are given images of apples and images of oranges learn to group them into apples and oranges, which feature is useful? <please select the best answer> A. Colors B. Round C. Shiny

q3.contents: For an SOFM, if the input pattern is [0.2, -0.1, 0.3, 0.2, 0.91], the neuron with which weight has the largest activation? <please select the best answer> A. [0.2, 0.1, 0.3, 0.2, 0.91] B. [0.2, -0.1, 0.5, 0.2, 0.69] C. [-0.5, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2, -0.61]

q4.contents: True or false: 'In the application of unsupervised learning, unsupervised learning can determine what is illegal.' <please select the best answer> True or False

q5.contents: In the process of using unsupervised learning to classify pictures of bananas and pictures of apples, which of the following features do you think is/are useful? Multiple answers can be chosen. <please select the answer> A. Color B. Shape C. Ear

q6.contents: In the process of SOFM learning, how will the radius change? <please select the best answer> A. Shrink B. Expand

q7.contents: In the first step of the SOFM learning, why can we set the weight to be random without affecting the result? <please input your answer>
q7.correct_answer: The initial neighbor size will cover the entire plane.

q8.contents: How can an SOFM place similar inputs? <please input your answer>
q8.correct_answer: Similar inputs are placed in nearby locations.

q9.contents: In an SOFM, what happens to the map if one kind of input is given more frequently than others? <please input your answer>

q10.contents: Please give an example of a self-organized structure. <please input your answer>
q10.correct_answer: Primary sensory area, or primary visual cortex

q1.contents: In an ART network, resonance is introduced to realize stable category formation. Resonance is established between which two layers? <please select the best answer> A. Input layer B. Interface layer C. Category layer

q2.contents: In an ART network, the input layer sends signals to the interface layer through ____. <please select the best answer> A. one-to-one connections B. full connections

q3.contents: In an ART network, the interface layer activates the category layer through ____. <please select the best answer> A. one-to-one connections B. full connections

q4.contents: Please write another name for “grouping” in unsupervised learning. <please input your answer>

q5.contents: Which person created Adaptive resonance theory1 (ART1)? <please select the best answer> A. David Hubel B. Stephen Grossberg C. Teuvo Kohonen

q6.contents: The unsupervised ANN that can compress usually has a middle layer that has a much ____ number of neurons. <please select the best answer> A. larger B. smaller

q7.contents: True or False: The k center points are selected from sample points.<please select the best answer> True or False

q8.contents: True or False: The clustering of K-means is that for each sample point, find the closest center point to it. <please select the best answer> True or False

q9.contents: True or False: After each clustering, there is no need to recalculate the center points. <please select the best answer> True or False

q10.contents: What is the end condition of the K-means algorithm? <please input your answer>
q10.correct_answer: The categories of sample points before and after the clustering are the same

q1.contents: True or False: Reinforcement learning gets inputs as well as produces outputs? <please select the best answer> A. True   B. False

q2.contents: In reinforcement learning, which two kinds of response does the agent get from its environment? <please select the best answer> A. Action, Reward B. Value, State C. Action, Value D. State, Reward

q3.contents: Please select one of the following which falls into the framework of reinforcement learning. <please select the best answer> A. A computer calculates the digits of π, a mathematical constant which is close to 3.14. B. A neural network learns to distinguish images with known categories as cars or bicycles. C. An autonomous car tries to adapt to changing road conditions without causing accidents. D. A software collects user information and provides personalized recommendations automatically.

q4.contents: In the game Pac-Man, the pac-man aims to eat as many beans in the maze as possible without getting caught by the ghosts (blue and pink avatars in the picture). A picture of the game Pac-Man. What is the agent of this game? <please input your answer>

q5.contents: In the game Pac-Man, the pac-man aims to eat as many beans in the maze as possible without getting caught by the ghosts (blue and pink avatars in the picture). A picture of the game Pac-Man. What is the state of this game? <please input your answer>

q6.contents: If the value (V) in the current state is only indicated by the current reward (r), what is the relationship between them if we consider the future effect but a consistent reward (i.e. the reward does not change for a state)? <please select the best answer> A. V = r B. V = V_old + 0.1 * (r - V_old) C. V = 0.1 * (r + 0.5 * V_next) D. V = V_old + 0.1 * ((r + 0.5 * V_next) - V_old)

q7.contents: In the formula V = V_old + α * ((r + g * V_next) - V_old), why do we introduce g? <please input your answer>
q7.correct_answer: the degree of the effect of the future situation

q8.contents: An agent receives 3 different rewards from the same state in 3 attempts. The 3 rewards are 20, 40, 45 respectively. Please use the formula V = Vold + 0.5 ✕ (r - Vold) and the initial V as 0 (Hint: Vold is 0 in the first calculation.) to calculate the final V of this state. <please input your answer>

q9.contents: An agent is at state (1,1). The possible next states are (1,2), (2,1) and (2,2). We have a lookup dictionary as follows. Which of the following is the V_next? A table of State (1,1), (1,2), (2,1), (2,2) with Value 10, 25, -10, 30 respectively. <please select the best answer> A. 10 B. 25 C.-10 D.30

q10.contents: If a problem or a game has a lot of states, like the Go game, then we will need a neural network. What relationship do we expect the neural network to capture? <please select the best answer> A. The reward an agent receive after action  B. The value of a given state of the environment C. The action to take under a state of the environment D. The next state of the environment after agent takes an action

q1.contents: True or False: The “reward” in the V-Learning means the total reward that an agent can expect to collect from that state and onwards into the future. <please select the best answer> A. True   B. False

q2.contents: Both V-learning and Q-learning determine how good the new state is , but Q-learning learns the evaluation specific to something in addition to the state. What is it? <please input your answer>

q3.contents: Q-Table is the main aim of steps of Q-Learning. Q-table records the long rewards for? <please select the best answer> A. different actions B. different states C. different actions taken in each state

q4.contents: If the value in the current state is only indicated by the current reward, but reward (r) is not always consistent, which of these formulas should we use to calculate Q value? <please select the best answer> A. Q=r B. Q_new = Q_old + 0.1*(r-Q_old) C. Q_old + 0.1* ((r+0.5*Q_next)-Q_old)

q5.contents: The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) currently defines 6 levels of driving automation. Please describe the main difference between Level 0-2 and Level 3-5? <please input your answer>
q5.correct_answer: Of the Level 0-2, the human monitors the driving environment, of the level 3-5, the autonomous cars can monitors the driving environment.

q6.contents: Can you name one issue or challenge that involves autonomous cars? <please input your answer>
q6.correct_answer: The responsibility for crashes or something else that applies or some else

q7.contents: Autonomous cars are under the framework. Please list some kinds of “environments” and “actions” in the situation of autonomous cars? <please input your answer>
q7.correct_answer: Environments: Many components. Traffic lights, pedestrian Actions: Brake, accelerate, turn left

q8.contents: Which kind of sensors bounce pulses of light off the car’s surroundings to measure distances? <please select the best answer> A. Radar sensors B. Video cameras C. Lidar sensors D. Ultrasonic sensors

q9.contents: An agent is at state (1,1), and the Q-table is as follows. Which of the actions should the agent take? Content of Q-table: The rewards of action going right/left/up/down at state (1,1) are 10,25,-10,30 respectively. The rewards of action going right/left/up/down at state (1,2) are 20,-10,15,25 respectively. The rewards of action going right/left/up/down at state (2,1) are 30,10,15,-10 respectively. The rewards of action going right/left/up/down at state (2,2) are 25,30,10,-10 respectively. <please select the best answer> A. going right B. going left C. going up D. going down

It tells what is in an image based on the information from hidden layers

An autonomous car tries to adapt to changing road conditions without causing accidents. D. A software collects user information and provides personalized recommendations automatically.

V = r B. V = V_old + 0.1 * (r - V_old) C. V = 0.1 * (r + 0.5 * V_next) D. V = V_old + 0.1 * ((r + 0.5 * V_next) - V_old)

The value is the place within which the reinforcement learning agent operates. D. The value is the best expected total reward an agent will receive given a state.
